citations.narrative:
A wired outdoor enclosure housing one adult male serval has a wall covered by a white plastic panel that is in poor repair.
Located on the right corner of it is an area that is approximately 1ft x 1.5 ft in size that has been worn creating a rough
textured surface. This worn area has pieces of plastic missing exposing the wire fencing beneath it and creating jagged
edges. A single piece of plastic that is approximately 1.5 inch in width by 2.5 inches in length, has been stripped partially
away from this panel.
Within this enclosure is a dog kennel located in the back left corner. The plastic panel is adjacent to the kennel and has
claw marks that start at approximately 1.5ft away from the top of the kennel. Above the kennel and approximately 8
inches from the torn plastic panel are 4 exposed roofing nails. These nails project from the metal roof exposing its shank
and tip into the enclosure.
Areas of worn and broken plastic can cause harm to the animal if ingested. The placement of the kennel next to the wall
can help create a platform for the animal to jump on. If used this way, the act of jumping on it can put the animal in close
contact with the sharp ends of the nails leading to potential injury. The licensee must ensure that the facility is constructed
of materials that are of appropriate strength for the animals involved. Indoor and outdoor facilities must be structurally
sound and be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain them.
To be corrected by 8/15/2025.

Two outdoor enclosures housing wild exotic felines were in need of cleaning. One enclosure had an adult male caracal
and contained a dog kennel. Inside the kennel was feces that appeared to be several days old. The feces took about one
third of the kennel area and was dry, gray to white in color, and rested upon compacted shavings and dry crumbled feces.
Licensee mentioned it is difficult to enter the enclosure as this animal is very fractious which delays the frequency of
cleaning.
A second outdoor enclosure, housing an adult male serval, had a layer of grime extending along the bottom of two walls.
The right side wall was a white plastic panel and on the back was a metal wall containing a doggy door. The grime was
dark brown to yellow in color and covered one third of the surface of the doggy door and the plastic panel. Along the
bottom right corner of the metal wall was a layer of cobwebs extending from the doggy door to the plastic panel. Within
the cobwebs were dirt, shavings, and underneath it a thin layer of amber colored organic material.
Cleaning of enclosures at regular intervals is necessary to prevent contamination of the animals, minimize spread of
disease, and reduce odors. The licensee shall ensure that excreta is removed from primary enclosures as often
necessary.
To be corrected by 8/15/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
A wired outdoor enclosure housing one adult male serval has a wall covered by a white plastic panel that is in poor repair. 
Located on the right corner of it is an area that is approximately 1ft x 1.5 ft in size that has been worn creating a rough 
textured surface. This worn area has pieces of plastic missing exposing the wire fencing beneath it and creating jagged 
edges. A single piece of plastic that is approximately 1.5 inch in width by 2.5 inches in length, has been stripped partially 
away from this panel. 
 
Within this enclosure is a dog kennel located in the back left corner. The plastic panel is adjacent to the kennel and has 
claw marks that start at approximately 1.5ft away from the top of the kennel. Above the kennel and approximately 8 
inches from the torn plastic panel are 4 exposed roofing nails. These nails project from the metal roof exposing its shank 
and tip into the enclosure. 
 
Areas of worn and broken plastic can cause harm to the animal if ingested. The placement of the kennel next to the wall 
can help create a platform for the animal to jump on. If used this way, the act of jumping on it can put the animal in close 
contact with the sharp ends of the nails leading to potential injury. The licensee must ensure that the facility is constructed 
of materials that are of appropriate strength for the animals involved. Indoor and outdoor facilities must be structurally 
sound and be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain them. 
 
To be corrected by 8/15/2025. 
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
Two outdoor enclosures housing wild exotic felines were in need of cleaning. One enclosure had an adult male caracal 
and contained a dog kennel. Inside the kennel was feces that appeared to be several days old. The feces took about one 
third of the kennel area and was dry, gray to white in color, and rested upon compacted shavings and dry crumbled feces. 
Licensee mentioned it is difficult to enter the enclosure as this animal is very fractious which delays the frequency of 
cleaning. 
 
A second outdoor enclosure, housing an adult male serval, had a layer of grime extending along the bottom of two walls.

The right side wall was a white plastic panel and on the back was a metal wall containing a doggy door. The grime was 
dark brown to yellow in color and covered one third of the surface of the doggy door and the plastic panel. Along the 
bottom right corner of the metal wall was a layer of cobwebs extending from the doggy door to the plastic panel. Within 
the cobwebs were dirt, shavings, and underneath it a thin layer of amber colored organic material. 
 
Cleaning of enclosures at regular intervals is necessary to prevent contamination of the animals, minimize spread of 
disease, and reduce odors. The licensee shall ensure that excreta is removed from primary enclosures as often 
necessary. 
 
To be corrected by 8/15/2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
 n

species.scientific: Exotic x Exotic Cat Hybrids. Panthera, Lynx, Puma, Leopardus, Caracal, Leptailurus, and Felis cross spp. (excluding exotic-domestic hybrids)
